awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Room-temperature electrophosphorescence from all-organic OLEDs
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop room-temperature electrophosphorescence (RT-EP) utilizing purely organic materials. These materials termed ?molecular alloys? are efficient phosphors as they transport charge, induce intersystem crossing from the singlet to triplet excited state, and lock the phosphors in a matrix preventing their nonradiative relaxation. 
The materials displaying RT-EP will be investigated using optical spectroscopy and force microscopy (AFM, STM, C-AFM, KPM). Studies of polaron/exciton dynamics in films via photoluminescence (PL)- and photoinduced absorption (PA)-detected magnetic resonance (PLDMR and PADMR, respectively) will be carried out together with studies of polaron and exciton dynamics in the OLEDs using electroluminescence (EL)- and electrical current-detected 
The intellectual merit: Electrophosphorescence from purely organic materials has so far been observed only at low temperature (~15 K), which prevents practical applications. The PVD materials termed ?molecular alloys? allow for efficient (EQE~3%) RT-EP in experimental devices. Thus, studies aimed at detailed understanding of the processes taking place in the all-organic phosphors-based devices are important.
The broader impacts are: Basic science proposed: An understanding of new all-organic materials that facilitate ISC while limiting nonradiative relaxation of the triplets and investigating physics of corresponding OLEDs will be achieved. Energy-conservation relevance: OLEDs as efficient light sources that would not require precious/heavy metals would be more environmentally friendly. Interdisciplinary Education: Collaboration between the two research groups with expertise in PVD, materials chemistry, condensed-matter physics, device fabrication and characterization will enrich education, encourage interdisciplinary thinking, and facilitate student exchange.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to demonstrate efficient bright all-organic (i.e., metal-free) organic LEDs (OLEDs). In most organic molecules, photogenerated singlet states (spin S = 0) return quickly to the ground state via prompt (~1 ns) fluorescence or a competing quenching process, or undergo intersystem crossing (ISC) to the triplet (S = 1) state. Radiative decay of the triplet to the ground state, i.e., weakly allowed phosphorescence, consequently involves yet another change of spin.1 Such phosphorescence is very efficient in some heavy metal chelates due to strong spin-orbit coupling,2-4 but it is often difficult to observe in metal-free compounds, particularly at room temperature (RT) where phonon (vibration)-driven nonradiative decay dominates.5

Intellectual Merit. Light emission in OLEDs is governed by spin statistics of electron-hole recombination, which dictates that the singlet and triplet exciton states are formed in a 1:3 ratio. Thus, efficient OLEDs require triplet phosphor emitters with a high photoluminescence (PL) quantum yield ηPL.2 

In this project we explored various deep blue OLEDs of the general structure MoOx/TCTA/NPB/TPBi/PPh3O/BPhen/CsF/Al, specifically

MoOx (5 nm)/TCTA (60 nm)/NPB (45 nm)/X/BPhen(30 nm)/CsF (1.5 nm)/Al(100 nm)

where

TCTA is tris(4-carbazoyl-9-ylphenyl)amine,

NPB is N,N′-bis(1-naphthyl)N,N′-diphenyl-1,1′-biphenyl-4,4′-diamine,

TPBi is 2,2′,2"-(1,3,5-Benzinetriyl)-tris(1-phenyl-1-H-benzimidazole),

PPh3O is triphenylphosphine oxide,

BPhen is 4,7-diphenyl-1,10-phenanthroline,

and the emitting layer X is a mixture of TPBi and PPh3O. The specific OLEDs we studied included devices with the structure above, where X was

(a) TPBi (14 nm)/PPh3O(15 nm),

(b) PPh3O (15 nm),

(c) TPBi:PPh3O (5:1) (14 nm)/PPh3O(15 nm),

(d) None,

(e) TPBi (30 nm),

(f) NPB:TPBi (1:1) (30 nm)

(g) NPB:TPBi (1:1) (30 nm)/TPBi (30 nm)

(h) NPB:TPBi (1:1) (30 nm)/TPBi (30 nm)/No BPhen

The electroluminescence (EL) spectra of the devices are shown in Fig. 1. Note that in all cases but (b) the emission peaks at 435 – 445 nm, i.e., in the deep violet/blue. The structure that yielded the brightest emission and highest efficiency was structure (c), whose EL reached a brightness of ~14,000 Cd/m2 and a luminous efficiency of 3.6 Cd/A. Fig. 2 shows the critical role of NPB in that emission, and Fig. 3 shows the current density and brightness vs bias of device (c).

In order to understand the nature of the exceptional performance of that device, we consider its electronic structure, which is shown in Fig. 4. As clearly seen, PPh3O has a very shallow lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) – only -1.5 eV. Thus, this material is very unusual: on the one hand, it is an excellent electron transport material;6,7 on the other hand, as soon as an electron in its LUMO encounters a “normal” molecule such as NPB or TPBi, with a LUMO level at ~-2.5 eV, it immediately decays to that deeper LUMO level. Hence, besides the documented NPB:TPBi exciplexes8 we also expect NPB:PPh3O exciplexes. Indeed, the EL spectra are consistent with these exciplexes.

The nature of these exciplexes is revealed by comparing the EL decay curves of the OLEDs in air vs within an inert atmosphere in a glove box (Fig. 5). As clearly seen, the air (i.e., oxygen) provides a nonradiative quenching channel for these exciplexes. Since oxygen only quenches triplet states, we conclude that the EL is due to triplet state exciplexes.

Broader Impacts. The project trained several graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the rapidly developing organic electronics interdisciplinary field.

In summary, we have demonstrated intense and efficient deep blue all-organic (i.e., metal-free) room temperature electrophosphoresence from TCTA/NPB/NPB:TPBi,TPBi:PPh3O/PPh3O/BPhen OLEDs. We are continuing to explore approaches to further the performance of these devices.

 

  1. M. Klessinger and J. Michl, Excited states and photochemistry of organic molecules. VCH, New York (1995).
  2. M. A. Baldo et al., Nature 395, 151 – 154 (1998).
  3. M. A. Baldo et al., Appl. Phys. Lett. 75, 4 (1999).
  4. C. Adachi et al., Appl. Phys. Lett. 77, 904 (2000).
  5. M. A. Baldo and S. R. Forrest, Phys. Rev. B  62, 10958 (2000).
  6. M. Y. Ha and D.G. Moon, Syn. Met. 158, 617–619 (2008).
  7. M.-Y. Ha and D.-G. Moon, Appl. Phys. Lett. 93, 043306 (2008).
  8. V. Jankus et al., Adv. Mater. 25, 1455–1459 (2013).

 

Figure Captions.

Fig. 1. (a) The EL spectra of devices (a) through (h).

Fig. 2. EL spectra of devices of structure (c) with and without NPB, obtained under the same conditions.

Fig. 3. Current density and brightness vs bias for Device (c) (with NPB).

Fig. 4. Electronic structure of Device (c).

Fig. 5. Transient PL decay of a film of 1:1 mixed NPB:PPh3O a) in air and b) encapsulated in a glovebox, and of NPB/TPBi:PPH3O(5:1)/PPh3O c) in air and d) encapsulated in a glovebox. The insets show the decay of the PL intensity with time.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Joseph Shinar
